title: Alcohol Withdrawal Seizure
icd10: F10.231 (Alcohol dependence with withdrawal with perceptual disturbance)
F10.232 (Alcohol dependence with withdrawal with perceptual disturbance)
scope: ** Evaluation and management of seizures in the context of alcohol withdrawal in adults, including acute seizure management, prevention of recurrence, thiamine supplementation, electrolyte correction, CIWA-Ar protocol monitoring, and disposition planning. Covers both single withdrawal seizures and recurrent withdrawal seizures. Excludes chronic epilepsy management, status epilepticus (see Status Epilepticus template), seizures from acute alcohol intoxication, and non-withdrawal alcohol-associated seizures (e.g., head trauma while intoxicated).

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Hypoglycemia is immediately reversible cause; alcoholics have depleted glycogen stores
Document current level; seizures typically occur as level falls (not at peak); helps timeline estimation
Essential/Core Labs.target: Document level and correlate with withdrawal timeline

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Infection screen; macrocytosis (chronic alcohol); thrombocytopenia (alcohol-related liver disease); baseline before treatment
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; macrocytosis suggests chronic alcohol use

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Electrolyte abnormalities (Na, K, Ca, Mg, glucose); renal function; hepatic function (alcoholic liver disease); AST:ALT ratio >2:1 suggests alcoholic hepatitis
Hypomagnesemia is common in chronic alcohol use and lowers seizure threshold; required cofactor for thiamine metabolism
Hypocalcemia lowers seizure threshold; common in alcoholism and malnutrition
Hypophosphatemia common in chronic alcohol use; refeeding risk
Concurrent illicit drug use (cocaine, amphetamines, benzodiazepines); polypharmacy
Essential/Core Labs.target: Identify co-intoxicants; benzodiazepine presence may mask withdrawal

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Post-ictal elevation expected; persistent elevation suggests ongoing seizure activity or sepsis
Essential/Core Labs.target: Mildly elevated post-ictal; should normalize within 1-2 hours

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Hepatic encephalopathy may coexist with or mimic alcohol withdrawal
Rhabdomyolysis from prolonged seizure activity or falls
Coagulopathy from liver disease; needed before LP if considered
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Normal; elevated INR suggests hepatic synthetic dysfunction
Normal or mild post-ictal metabolic acidosis

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Cardiac stress from seizure, autonomic surge, or arrhythmia
Thyroid dysfunction can affect seizure threshold
Affects treatment decisions (benzodiazepine safety, imaging); eclampsia consideration
Confirms deficiency; do NOT delay treatment for result
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Low suggests deficiency; treat empirically regardless

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Often co-deficient with thiamine in chronic alcohol use
Folate deficiency common in chronic alcohol use; contributes to macrocytic anemia
Nutritional status assessment; short half-life reflects recent intake

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Subtherapeutic levels if patient on chronic ASMs
Synthetic drugs, medications not on standard screen; methanol, ethylene glycol
If clinical presentation is atypical for simple withdrawal seizure
HIV-associated CNS disease; higher prevalence in some populations with alcohol use disorder
Neurosyphilis; risk factor overlap with alcohol use
Hepatitis B/C common with alcohol use disorder; affects treatment decisions
Osmolar gap to exclude methanol or ethylene glycol poisoning

Essential/First-line.timing: Immediately; alcoholic patients at high risk for subdural hematoma, traumatic hemorrhage, and falls
Essential/First-line.target: No hemorrhage, mass, or acute stroke; subdural hematoma common in chronic alcoholism

Essential/First-line.timing: Within 24 hours if any atypical features or concern for non-convulsive status; not required for classic single withdrawal seizure
Essential/First-line.target: No ongoing epileptiform activity; generalized slowing expected in withdrawal

Extended.item: MRI brain with and without contrast (CPT 70553)
Extended.timing: Within 24-48 hours if first seizure, focal neurologic deficit, focal seizure semiology, or CT findings requiring further evaluation
Extended.target: Structural lesion, cortical abnormality, Wernicke changes (medial thalami, mammillary bodies, periaqueductal gray)

Extended.timing: If altered mental status persists beyond expected post-ictal period; concern for non-convulsive status epilepticus
Aspiration risk post-ictal; concurrent pneumonia in malnourished patients
Arrhythmia from electrolyte abnormalities (hypomagnesemia, hypokalemia); QTc prolongation; cardiomyopathy
Extended.target: Normal sinus rhythm; correct QTc prolongation

Rare/Specialized.timing: Liver assessment if hepatic disease suspected

Acute/Emergent.indication: Acute seizure cessation and withdrawal seizure prevention

dosing.instructions: 2-4 mg IV push over 2 min; may repeat q5-10min; max 8-10 mg in first hour; preferred in hepatic impairment (no hepatic metabolism)

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Acute narrow-angle glaucoma; severe respiratory depression without ventilator support
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: RR, O2 sat, BP, sedation level; airway equipment at bedside

Acute/Emergent.indication: Acute seizure cessation; preferred for smooth withdrawal prophylaxis due to long-acting metabolites

dosing.instructions: 5-10 mg IV push over 2-5 min; may repeat q5-10min; max 30 mg in first hour; long-acting active metabolite (desmethyldiazepam) provides smoother withdrawal coverage

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Severe hepatic impairment (use lorazepam instead); severe respiratory depression
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: RR, O2 sat, BP, sedation level; active metabolites accumulate in liver disease

Acute/Emergent.indication: Acute seizure if no IV access

dosing.instructions: 10 mg IM (if >=40 kg) or 0.2 mg/kg IM; single dose; obtain IV access urgently

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: RR, O2 sat; prepare IV access immediately

Acute/Emergent.indication: Wernicke encephalopathy prevention and treatment; MUST give before or with glucose

dosing.instructions: 500 mg IV TID for 3 days (diluted in 100 mL NS over 30 min), then 250 mg IV daily for 5 days; give BEFORE glucose

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Rare anaphylaxis (extremely uncommon); have epinephrine available

dosing.instructions: 50 mL IV push (25 g) if glucose <70 or unknown; ALWAYS give thiamine first or simultaneously

Acute/Emergent.indication: Hypomagnesemia correction; required cofactor for thiamine metabolism

dosing.instructions: 2 g IV over 1 hour initially; then 1 g IV q6h until Mg >2.0 mg/dL; severe deficiency may require 4-6 g over first 24 hours

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Renal failure (monitor levels closely); myasthenia gravis
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Mg levels q12-24h; deep tendon reflexes; respiratory status; renal function

Acute/Emergent.indication: Maintain oxygenation during and after seizure

dosing.instructions: 2-4 L nasal cannula or non-rebreather as needed to maintain O2 sat >94%

Acute/Emergent.indication: Volume resuscitation; chronic alcohol users are often dehydrated

dosing.instructions: NS or LR bolus 500-1000 mL, then 150-250 mL/hr maintenance; add dextrose (D5NS) once thiamine given; correct dehydration

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Fluid overload; severe hyponatremia (use caution with rate)
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: I/O, BP, Na; avoid rapid correction of hyponatremia (max 8-10 mEq/L per 24h)

Symptomatic/Withdrawal Management.indication: Symptom-triggered withdrawal management (CIWA-Ar based); preferred for mild-moderate withdrawal when oral route available

dosing.instructions: CIWA-Ar >=10: give 25-100 mg PO q1h until CIWA <10; then PRN dosing; typical total day 1: 200-400 mg; taper over 3-5 days; long half-life provides smooth coverage

Symptomatic/Withdrawal Management.contraindications: Severe hepatic impairment (use lorazepam); respiratory depression; acute intoxication
Symptomatic/Withdrawal Management.monitoring: CIWA-Ar q1h during active treatment, then q4h when stable; RR, sedation level

Symptomatic/Withdrawal Management.indication: Symptom-triggered withdrawal management; alternative to chlordiazepoxide

dosing.instructions: CIWA-Ar >=10: give 10-20 mg PO q1-2h until CIWA <10; then PRN dosing; taper over 3-5 days; long-acting metabolites

Symptomatic/Withdrawal Management.contraindications: Severe hepatic impairment (use lorazepam); respiratory depression
Symptomatic/Withdrawal Management.monitoring: CIWA-Ar q1h during active treatment, then q4h; RR, sedation level

Symptomatic/Withdrawal Management.indication: Symptom-triggered withdrawal management; preferred in liver disease (no hepatic metabolism required)

dosing.instructions: CIWA-Ar >=10: give 1-2 mg PO q1-2h until CIWA <10; then PRN dosing; shorter half-life requires more frequent dosing; preferred if AST/ALT elevated or known cirrhosis

Symptomatic/Withdrawal Management.monitoring: CIWA-Ar q1h during active treatment, then q4h; RR, sedation level; shorter acting - watch for rebound

Symptomatic/Withdrawal Management.indication: Withdrawal management in severe liver disease; no active metabolites

dosing.instructions: 15-30 mg PO q6-8h; CIWA-Ar guided; no active metabolites; safest in severe hepatic impairment

Symptomatic/Withdrawal Management.monitoring: CIWA-Ar; shorter half-life requires frequent monitoring

Symptomatic/Withdrawal Management.indication: Folate deficiency correction; common in chronic alcohol use

dosing.instructions: 1 mg PO daily; continue long-term if alcohol use disorder

Symptomatic/Withdrawal Management.indication: Nutritional supplementation; multiple micronutrient deficiencies in chronic alcohol use

dosing.instructions: 1 multivitamin tablet PO daily

Symptomatic/Withdrawal Management.indication: Hypokalemia correction; common in alcoholism and with vomiting

dosing.instructions: Replace per level: K 3.0-3.5: 40 mEq PO; K <3.0: 20-40 mEq IV over 1-2 hours; check Mg (must replete Mg for K to correct)

Symptomatic/Withdrawal Management.monitoring: K levels q6-12h; cardiac monitor if IV replacement

dosing.instructions: 1-2 g calcium gluconate IV over 10-20 min; check Mg (required for calcium homeostasis)

Symptomatic/Withdrawal Management.monitoring: Ionized calcium; cardiac monitor during infusion

Symptomatic/Withdrawal Management.indication: Hypophosphatemia correction; common in alcoholism and refeeding

doseOptions.orderSentence: Phosphorus replacement 15-45 mmol IV or 250 mg PO IV/PO

dosing.instructions: Mild (2.0-2.5): K-Phos 250 mg PO TID; Moderate (1.0-2.0): NaPhos 15-30 mmol IV over 4-6h; Severe (<1.0): 30-45 mmol IV over 6h
dosing.orderSentence: Phosphorus replacement 15-45 mmol IV or 250 mg PO IV/PO

dosing.instructions: 4 mg IV q8h PRN; may also use PO/ODT formulation

Symptomatic/Withdrawal Management.indication: Headache and pain management; avoid NSAIDs due to bleeding and hepatic risk

dosing.instructions: 650-1000 mg PO/IV q6h PRN; max 2000 mg/day in liver disease (3000 mg/day if normal liver)

Symptomatic/Withdrawal Management.monitoring: LFTs if prolonged use; reduce dose in liver disease

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Refractory alcohol withdrawal not controlled by benzodiazepines alone; synergistic with benzodiazepines at GABA-A receptor

dosing.instructions: 130-260 mg IV q15-30 min, titrate to symptom control; max loading 10-20 mg/kg; maintenance 32-65 mg IV/PO q8-12h; can be used as primary agent or adjunct

Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: RR (respiratory depression additive with benzodiazepines); sedation; intubation equipment at bedside; phenobarbital level if prolonged use

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Severe refractory withdrawal with seizures requiring ICU-level sedation; GABA-A and NMDA activity

doseOptions.orderSentence: Propofol infusion 1-2 mg/kg bolus, then 20-80 mcg/kg/min IV

dosing.instructions: Load 1-2 mg/kg IV bolus; infusion 20-80 mcg/kg/min; titrate to RASS -2 to -3; max 200 mcg/kg/min; limit duration <48h at high doses
dosing.orderSentence: Propofol infusion 1-2 mg/kg bolus, then 20-80 mcg/kg/min IV

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Propofol infusion syndrome risk; egg/soy allergy
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: cEEG if concern for seizures; triglycerides q24h; CPK; metabolic acidosis panel; hemodynamics

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Adjunctive sedation for withdrawal; reduces benzodiazepine requirement; treats sympathetic hyperactivity

dosing.instructions: Start 0.2 mcg/kg/hr; titrate to effect (max 1.5 mcg/kg/hr); no loading dose in hemodynamically unstable patients; reduces BZD requirements by 30-50%

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Severe bradycardia; 2nd/3rd degree heart block; hypotension
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: HR, BP (bradycardia and hypotension); does NOT prevent seizures - must continue benzodiazepines

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Adjunctive for withdrawal seizure prevention when benzodiazepines insufficient; NOT a substitute for benzodiazepines

dosing.instructions: 20-40 mg/kg IV over 30 min; then 250-500 mg IV q8h; monitor ammonia

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Pregnancy (teratogenic); hepatic disease (common in this population); pancreatitis; mitochondrial disease
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: LFTs, ammonia, platelets; hepatotoxicity risk higher in alcoholic liver disease; pancreatitis risk

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Adjunctive seizure prophylaxis; NOT a substitute for benzodiazepines for withdrawal management; may be considered if concurrent epilepsy diagnosis or concern for non-withdrawal seizures

dosing.instructions: 1000-1500 mg IV q12h; does NOT treat withdrawal syndrome itself; use as adjunct only

Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Behavioral changes; renal function; does NOT replace benzodiazepines

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Alternative/adjunctive for mild-moderate withdrawal; may reduce withdrawal severity and seizure risk; evidence in European literature

dosing.instructions: Start 200 mg TID on day 1; may increase to 400 mg TID; taper over 5-7 days; can be used alone for mild withdrawal or as adjunct

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Hepatic disease; bone marrow suppression; AV block; HLA-B*1502 positive (Asian populations)
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: CBC, LFTs, sodium (hyponatremia risk); drug interactions

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Adjunctive for mild-moderate withdrawal symptoms; may reduce benzodiazepine requirements; limited evidence for seizure prevention

dosing.instructions: Start 300-600 mg TID; may increase to 900 mg TID; taper over 5-7 days; limited evidence for seizure prevention; better evidence for anxiety/insomnia symptoms

Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Sedation; renal function; NOT a substitute for benzodiazepines in moderate-severe withdrawal

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology consult for first-time seizure evaluation to exclude non-withdrawal etiology and guide workup
Addiction medicine or psychiatry consult for alcohol use disorder treatment initiation (naltrexone, acamprosate, medication-assisted treatment)
Social work consult for substance abuse resources, rehabilitation program referral, and discharge planning
Gastroenterology/Hepatology referral if liver disease identified (elevated LFTs, cirrhosis on imaging, coagulopathy)
Nutrition/Dietitian consult for malnutrition assessment and refeeding syndrome prevention
ICU consult if CIWA-Ar >20, recurrent seizures despite treatment, or hemodynamic instability
Physical therapy for fall risk assessment and gait evaluation if ataxia or peripheral neuropathy present
Outpatient neurology follow-up in 2-4 weeks for seizure evaluation completion (MRI, EEG review) and determination if chronic ASM therapy needed
Primary care follow-up within 1 week of discharge for ongoing alcohol cessation support and medical management
Alcohol treatment program referral (inpatient rehabilitation, intensive outpatient program, or Alcoholics Anonymous)

Patient Instructions.item: Return to ED immediately if another seizure occurs, seizure lasts >5 minutes, difficulty breathing, persistent confusion, chest pain, or severe tremors/hallucinations (may indicate progression to delirium tremens)
Do NOT drive until cleared by neurology; seizures impair driving safety and most states require seizure-free interval
Do NOT stop drinking alcohol abruptly without medical supervision as this can provoke seizures and life-threatening withdrawal (seek medical detoxification)
Take all medications exactly as prescribed, especially benzodiazepines during the taper period; do NOT stop benzodiazepines abruptly
Avoid operating heavy machinery, working at heights, swimming alone, or bathing alone until seizure-free and cleared by neurology
Inform family members or housemates about seizure first aid: stay with person, protect head, do NOT put anything in mouth, time the seizure, call 911 if seizure lasts >5 minutes
Eat regular balanced meals to prevent hypoglycemia and maintain electrolyte balance; malnutrition increases seizure risk
Keep follow-up appointments with neurology and addiction medicine; recurrent withdrawal episodes worsen seizure severity via kindling
Wear medical identification bracelet indicating seizure history
Understand that each episode of alcohol withdrawal increases future seizure risk (kindling phenomenon); this is a progressive condition

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Alcohol cessation is the definitive treatment and most important intervention to prevent recurrent withdrawal seizures
Supervised medical detoxification for future alcohol cessation attempts to prevent withdrawal seizures and delirium tremens
Balanced nutrition with emphasis on thiamine-containing foods (whole grains, legumes, lean meats) to rebuild depleted stores
Sleep hygiene: maintain regular sleep schedule; sleep deprivation independently lowers seizure threshold
Thiamine supplementation 100 mg PO daily indefinitely if continued alcohol use or malnutrition risk persists
Folic acid supplementation 1 mg PO daily for chronic deficiency prevention
Avoid illicit drugs (especially stimulants: cocaine, amphetamines) which independently lower seizure threshold
Stress management and coping strategies as alternatives to alcohol use; consider cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT)
Home safety modifications: remove sharp furniture edges, avoid glass shower doors, keep bathroom door unlocked due to seizure risk
Regular exercise to improve overall health and support alcohol recovery; avoid extreme exertion that leads to dehydration
Engage with peer support groups (Alcoholics Anonymous, SMART Recovery) for sustained sobriety
Avoid medications that lower seizure threshold (tramadol, bupropion at high doses, certain antipsychotics) without neurology guidance

differential.features: Focal onset features, aura, focal neurologic findings, seizures not temporally related to withdrawal timeline (6-48h)
differential.tests: MRI brain, EEG, detailed seizure semiology; focal epileptiform discharges on EEG

differential.features: History of falls or trauma (may be unrecognized); focal neurologic deficits; headache
differential.tests: CT head (STAT); chronic SDH common in alcoholics

differential.features: Diaphoresis, tremor, confusion; rapid improvement with glucose correction
Asterixis, gradual onset, jaundice, ascites; no discrete seizure activity; elevated ammonia
differential.tests: Ammonia level, LFTs, abdominal exam; EEG shows triphasic waves

differential.features: Occurs later (48-96h); prominent hallucinations, severe autonomic instability, agitation; altered sensorium is continuous (not post-ictal)
differential.tests: CIWA-Ar scoring; clinical timeline; seizures may precede DTs

differential.features: Fever, nuchal rigidity, photophobia; may have rash; progressive altered mental status
differential.tests: LP with CSF analysis; blood cultures; BioFire ME Panel

differential.features: Oculomotor dysfunction (nystagmus, ophthalmoplegia), ataxia, confusion; may coexist with withdrawal seizures
differential.tests: MRI brain (thalamic/mammillary body changes); thiamine level; clinical response to thiamine

differential.features: Anion gap metabolic acidosis, osmolar gap, visual disturbance (methanol), renal failure (ethylene glycol)
differential.tests: Osmolarity, osmolar gap, specific levels if available; ABG

differential.features: Sympathomimetic signs (tachycardia, hypertension, mydriasis); seizure during intoxication rather than withdrawal
differential.tests: Urine drug screen; clinical timeline (seizure during use, not after stopping)

differential.features: History of head trauma, focal deficits, scalp laceration/hematoma; may be unrecognized in intoxicated patients
differential.tests: CT head; clinical exam for signs of trauma

differential.features: Prolonged duration, asynchronous movements, eye closure, preserved awareness with bilateral movements, no post-ictal confusion
differential.tests: Video-EEG; normal prolactin drawn within 20 min

differential.features: Sodium <120 mEq/L; gradual or rapid onset depending on acuity; often with beer potomania or SIADH
differential.tests: Serum sodium, osmolality; clinical response to sodium correction

differential.features: History of TB treatment, refractory seizures, metabolic acidosis; pyridoxine-responsive
differential.tests: Medication history; responds to pyridoxine (vitamin B6)

evidence.recommendation: Benzodiazepines are first-line treatment for alcohol withdrawal seizures
Symptom-triggered therapy (CIWA-Ar) reduces total benzodiazepine dose and treatment duration vs fixed-schedule dosing
Phenytoin is NOT effective for alcohol withdrawal seizures
evidence.source: [Rathlev NK et al. Ann Emerg Med 1994;24:116-118](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/8135426/); [Chance JF. Ann Emerg Med 1991;20:520-522](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/2024792/)

evidence.recommendation: Lorazepam IV reduces seizure recurrence in alcohol withdrawal
evidence.source: [D'Onofrio G et al. Ann Emerg Med 1999;34:725-731](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/10637988/)

evidence.recommendation: High-dose IV thiamine (500 mg TID) for Wernicke encephalopathy prevention in at-risk patients
evidence.source: [Ambrose ML et al. J Clin Neurosci 2001;8:256-259](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11825301/); [Thomson AD et al. Alcohol Alcohol 2002;37:513-521](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/12414541/)

evidence.recommendation: Alcohol withdrawal seizures occur in 6-48 hours after last drink; peak at 12-24 hours
evidence.source: [Victor M, Brausch C. Electroencephalogr Clin Neurophysiol 1967;22:63-70](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/6065665/)

evidence.recommendation: Kindling phenomenon: progressive worsening of withdrawal with repeated episodes
evidence.source: [Ballenger JC, Post RM. Br J Psychiatry 1978;133:1-14](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/352467/)

evidence.recommendation: CT head recommended for all first alcohol withdrawal seizures due to high incidence of concurrent traumatic pathology

evidence.source: [Wilson A, Bhagwan T. Cochrane Database Syst Rev 2001](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11405969/)

evidence.recommendation: Phenobarbital as adjunct or alternative for severe alcohol withdrawal
ASAM Clinical Practice Guideline on alcohol withdrawal management
ACEP Clinical Policy on alcohol withdrawal management
evidence.source: [Wolf SJ et al. Ann Emerg Med 2022;79:e1-e26](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/37588456/)

evidence.recommendation: Dexmedetomidine as adjunctive therapy reduces benzodiazepine requirements in alcohol withdrawal
Gabapentin and carbamazepine may have role in mild-moderate alcohol withdrawal
evidence.source: [Myrick H et al. Am J Psychiatry 2009;166:1025-1034](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20108855/)

evidence.recommendation: Alcohol withdrawal seizures are provoked/acute symptomatic seizures and do not establish a diagnosis of epilepsy
Thiamine must be given before glucose to prevent precipitating Wernicke encephalopathy
evidence.source: Expert consensus; [Galvin R et al. Eur J Intern Med 2010;21:509-514](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/21294435/)

monitoring.action: Persistent AMS â cEEG; focal findings â urgent imaging

monitoring.action: Tachycardia/hypertension â increase benzodiazepines; fever â infection workup

monitoring.action: Supplemental O2; assess airway; chest X-ray

monitoring.frequency: q6h during active withdrawal; QAC if on D5 fluids
q6-12h during active withdrawal; daily once stable
monitoring.action: Replete deficiencies; monitor sodium correction rate
Adjust medications metabolized hepatically; hepatology consult if worsening
Treat arrhythmia; correct electrolytes; avoid QT-prolonging medications

monitoring.frequency: q8h on floor; q1-4h in ICU
monitoring.action: Adjust IV fluids; assess for renal function

disposition.criteria: Single withdrawal seizure; returned to baseline neurologic function; CIWA <10 for >24 hours; stable vital signs; able to tolerate oral medications; no dangerous structural findings on CT; reliable adult supervision for 72 hours; outpatient follow-up arranged (neurology within 2-4 weeks, PCP within 1 week); understands return precautions and driving restriction; willing to engage with alcohol cessation resources

Multiple seizures; prolonged post-ictal period (>2 hours); CIWA 10-20 requiring ongoing benzodiazepine titration; electrolyte abnormalities requiring IV correction; new structural lesion on imaging requiring monitoring; unable to tolerate oral medications; no reliable supervision at home; history of delirium tremens or complicated withdrawal; significant comorbidities (liver disease, malnutrition)

Recurrent seizures despite benzodiazepine treatment; status epilepticus; CIWA >20 requiring high-dose or continuous benzodiazepine infusion; hemodynamic instability; respiratory compromise; delirium tremens; need for continuous EEG monitoring; phenobarbital or propofol infusion required; aspiration pneumonia with respiratory failure

Neurology unavailable for consultation; continuous EEG monitoring unavailable; ICU services unavailable for refractory withdrawal; need for neurosurgical intervention (e.g., subdural hematoma evacuation)
